title: NCAA Men’s March Madness Project
text:
# install and load packages
if(!require(pacman))
  install.packages("pacman")

pacman::p_load(tidyverse,
               janitor)

devtools::install_github("tidyverse/dsbox")

library(tidyverse)

title: NCAA Men’s March Madness Project
text:
Dataset

team_results <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-03-26/team-results.csv') |>
  clean_names()
public_picks <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/main/data/2024/2024-03-26/public-picks.csv') |>
  clean_names()


view(team_results)
view(public_picks)

A brief description of your dataset including its provenance, dimensions, etc. as well as the reason why you chose this dataset.
Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information.

title: NCAA Men’s March Madness Project
text:
Questions

Does a team’s overall popularity have any correlation to its success in March Madness?
How do public predictions vary across the tournament based on experienced teams?

title: NCAA Men’s March Madness Project
text:
Analysis plan

Question 1



Using the team_results data, I will be using the variables wins (w), win percentage (win), and other indicators of tournament advancement (r64, champ, etc.).
Using the public_picks data, I will use the cross reference the data from team_results_data and compare the percent of people who picked the team to win finals, final 4, etc. All of those (finals, f4, e8, etc.) are variable names as a percent character.
I will clean the data by converting character columns to numeric, and also merge both data sets in order to match their round-specific data points for the visualization.
I will create a new variable that determines the “overall” public popularity. I can do this by creating a new variable that computes the mean of pick percentages. Alternatively, I can compute a weighted score using a mathematical point model system that weighs later rounds as more valuable.
Finally, I will develop the visualization. I have not decided yet, but I am leaning towards using a histogram, box plot, or scatter plot with a linear regression model.






Question 2



Using the team_results data, I will convert the amount of games played by teams into a categorical variable. This variable will be called “Experience level” and will be categorized as low, high, and medium (I may adjust this later).
Using the public_picks data, I will revisit the round percentage popularity and compute the variability (using range, standard deviations, mean, etc.)
Using the new variables and data, merge the data sets and prepare for visualization.
Utilize statistical testing and plot data to draw conclusions and interpretation

title: Project Title
text:
March madness is the NCAA Division 1 annual basketball tournament. It is single-elimination based tournament, and the data I will be using is from 2008-2024. 2020 is not included because of Covid. There are two data sets that will be used: Team Results and Public Picks. Let’s start with the simpler one: the Public Picks data set contains the percentage of people who picked the team to win game in the rounds 64, 32, 16, 8, final 4, and finals for the 2024 year.
The second data set is Team Results, and contains data from 2008-2023. This data set contains more variables, such as PAKE (performance against Komputer expectations) and PASE (Performance against seed expectations), along with total historical games teams have played in the tournament as well as how often they have made top 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, finals, and champion. There are also a couple of indicator variables, such as f4percent and champpercent, which notes likelihood of a team getting at least 1 final four or at least 1 championship.

title: Project title
text:
Math Expressions
You can write LaTeX math expressions inside a pair of dollar signs, e.g. $\alpha+\beta$ renders \(\alpha + \beta\). You can use the display style with double dollar signs:
$$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$
\[
\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i
\]
Limitations:

The source code of a LaTeX math expression must be in one line, unless it is inside a pair of double dollar signs, in which case the starting $$ must appear in the very beginning of a line, followed immediately by a non-space character, and the ending $$ must be at the end of a line, led by a non-space character;
There should not be spaces after the opening $ or before the closing $.

title: Project title
text:
Feeling adventurous?

You are welcomed to use the default styling of the slides. In fact, that’s what I expect majority of you will do. You will differentiate yourself with the content of your presentation.
But some of you might want to play around with slide styling. Some solutions for this can be found at https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs.

title: Project Title
text:
March madness is the NCAA Division 1 annual basketball tournament. It is single-elimination based tournament, and the data I will be using is from 2008-2024. 2020 is not included because of Covid. There are two data sets that will be used: Team Results and Public Picks. Let’s start with the simpler one: the Public Picks data set contains the percentage of people who picked the team to win game in the rounds 64, 32, 16, 8, final 4, and finals for the 2024 year.
The second data set is Team Results, and contains data from 2008-2023. This data set contains more variables, such as PAKE (performance against Komputer expectations) and PASE (Performance against seed expectations), along with total historical games teams have played in the tournament as well as how often they have made top 64, 32, 16, 8, 4, finals, and champion. There are also a couple of indicator variables, such as f4percent and champpercent, which notes likelihood of a team getting at least 1 final four or at least 1 championship.

title: Project Title
text:
Question 1:
How well does past performance from 2008-2023 correlate with predictions for the 2024 tournament?
